results.title: Friction: a first film
results.brief_description: A series of blocks and springs helps students recognise frictional force as something apart from the force of gravity. Suitable for lower secondary level.

results.title: Attraction of gravity
results.brief_description: The relationship of mass and distance to the force of gravity are explored by careful duplicating of Cavendish’s and Boy’s experiments. Understanding gravity helps us to explain the movements of the planets and the changes in weight of astronauts as they land on the moon. Suitable for upper secondary levels.

results.title: Animal behaviour: a first film
results.creator_credit: Norman Bean and Norman Bean Films
results.brief_description: Animals have behaviour patterns that are caused by stimuli. The film is open ended as the viewer is left to work out the stimuli for various types of behaviour. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Red Sunday: the story of the Battle of Little Big Horn
results.creator_credit: James B. Kelly, James R. Graff, Robert A. Henkel and Pyramid Films
results.brief_description: A study of the Battle of Little Big Horn which weaves a wealth of original drawings (mostly done by Indian who were participants of the actual battle), photographs and paintings, both by Indian and white artists with recreated live cavalry action on the site itself. Narrated by John McIntire. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: The Unknown Eiffel
results.creator_credit: Joan Laskoff and Lennox Art Group
results.brief_description: Biography of Alexandre Gustave Eiffel whoo pioneered metal construction techniques, including prefabrication. Shows some of his most famous works, quotations from Eiffel’s own writings, drawings and plans and contemporary paintings and drawings are used throughout.

results.title: Santa Claus is coming tonight
results.creator_credit: Pierre Heberrt, Gaston Sarault and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A combination of live-action footage and animation creates a film that is an effective reminder that Christmas is fast disappearing under a mountain of crass commercialism: Santa Clauses that operate on a tight time schedule, a landscape shorn of evergreens, a cornucopia of toys and gadgets, and a cacophony of noise. The story is biting, the drawings are pointed, and the feast of Christmas stands divested of its slick trappings.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Pierre Heberrt, Gaston Sarault and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Graphic communication
results.creator_credit: Alexander Milsky and Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre
results.brief_description: A series of basic geometric shapes are used to illustrates how signs, symbols and diagrams can be employed to represent written or verbal information. Quite complex concepts can often be conveyed effectively by the use of simple symbols.

results.title: Being right: can you still lose?
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Questions, Answers.”.
An excerpt from the feature ” Ride a wild pony”, which has an Australian setting. Conflict flares when two children claim ownership of a wild pony. A judge settles the dispute by allowing the pony to decide. The film centres on how the children cope with the decision. The aim of the film is to allow children to explore the concepts of winning and losing and how to deal with them. Suitable for middle and upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: What about tomorrow?
results.creator_credit: Dave Smallin and A Dave Smallin Production
results.brief_description: The consumption of alcohol by adolescents is the subject of this dramatized open-ended film. The influences upon teenagers to take up drinking are indicated and one young man is confronted with the possible long term effects of alcohol misuse.
